pullrequest.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

content.raw:
We're now using a condition variable to wait for time to elapse between messages: bf11a5e + 802c892 + 845c241

This will not inherently respond to a Ctrl-C, but a developer can interrupt the wait at any time by calling the `Playback::Stop()` function. The developer can then redirect the SIGINT signal to call `Playback::Stop()` when an end-user presses Ctrl+C.
content.html:
We're now using a condition variable to wait for time to elapse between messages: bf11a5e + 802c892 + 845c241

This will not inherently respond to a Ctrl-C, but a developer can interrupt the wait at any time by calling the Playback::Stop() function. The developer can then redirect the SIGINT signal to call Playback::Stop() when an end-user presses Ctrl+C.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

content.raw:
Notice that the condition is `!=`, which means this function will return here if the publisher already exists, because there is no need to create a new one.

The return value of this function is `true` if a new publisher was created, and `false` if no publisher needed to be created, because one already existed that matches the requested (topic, type) pair.
content.html:
Notice that the condition is !=, which means this function will return here if the publisher already exists, because there is no need to create a new one.

The return value of this function is true if a new publisher was created, and false if no publisher needed to be created, because one already existed that matches the requested (topic, type) pair.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

content.raw:
Is not possible to interrupt this `sleep_for`, right? I'm imagining a situation where we logged two messages with one minute difference. Can I interrupt this lambda (e.g.: CTRL-C) without waiting one minute and terminating the thread cleanly?

Maybe an alternative might be to use `condition_variable::wait_until()`.
content.html:
Is not possible to interrupt this sleep_for, right? I'm imagining a situation where we logged two messages with one minute difference. Can I interrupt this lambda (e.g.: CTRL-C) without waiting one minute and terminating the thread cleanly?

Maybe an alternative might be to use condition_variable::wait_until().

pull_request.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

content.raw:
Alternatively, we could have `stop` be a `std::atomic_bool` instead of ordinary `bool`.

I suspect it won't make a difference, since `bool` can't exist in a partially-written state, making it largely unaffected by race condition issues. Still, making it explicitly atomic would be good practice anyway.
content.html:
Alternatively, we could have stop be a std::atomic_bool instead of ordinary bool.

I suspect it won't make a difference, since bool can't exist in a partially-written state, making it largely unaffected by race condition issues. Still, making it explicitly atomic would be good practice anyway.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

content.raw: I think a situation where there are no messages to play back is a strange enough edge case that we should be explicit about when it occurs. It seems unlikely that someone would intentionally request to begin a playback that will result in no messages being produced. I suspect it's more likely that the user made some mistake in the process of setting up the playback, so if we quietly exit with success here, then it might be hard for them to track down why they aren't getting any messages.
content.html: I think a situation where there are no messages to play back is a strange enough edge case that we should be explicit about when it occurs. It seems unlikely that someone would intentionally request to begin a playback that will result in no messages being produced. I suspect it's more likely that the user made some mistake in the process of setting up the playback, so if we quietly exit with success here, then it might be hard for them to track down why they aren't getting any messages.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

content.raw:
The catch with that approach is that the regex pattern would get saved, and every new topic that gets advertised would be checked against that pattern. However, the pattern would only apply to this single topic, which we have already subscribed to, so performing that check would be wasteful.

That said, we can look into making this code DRY-er, maybe by refactoring the `AddTopic(~)` functions to use a common implementation function of some kind.
content.html:
The catch with that approach is that the regex pattern would get saved, and every new topic that gets advertised would be checked against that pattern. However, the pattern would only apply to this single topic, which we have already subscribed to, so performing that check would be wasteful.

That said, we can look into making this code DRY-er, maybe by refactoring the AddTopic(~) functions to use a common implementation function of some kind.

content.raw: Just checking, can we convert the topic to a regex and call the other `AddTopic()` function? Maybe this way we can avoid some code duplication.

pull_request.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

content.raw:
Shouldn't we just end instead of returning an error in this case? 

If I'm the client that uses this functionality and I want to playback an empty list of messages, maybe the function should return immediately but succeed. That way, if I get an error, I know that something abnormal happened and I should notify the user, exit, etc.
content.html:
Shouldn't we just end instead of returning an error in this case?

If I'm the client that uses this functionality and I want to playback an empty list of messages, maybe the function should return immediately but succeed. That way, if I get an error, I know that something abnormal happened and I should notify the user, exit, etc.

content.raw: Should we move `lk` before line 176 to make sure we evaluate `this->stop` after the lock?
content.html: Should we move lk before line 176 to make sure we evaluate this->stop after the lock?

pull_request.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 6: Playback ignition transport topics

content.raw: Just checking: If I understand correctly, when the topic doesn't exist, we create an entry in the map for it. However, if the type doesn't exist, we return. Is there any reason for not creating the type and continue advertising the topic?
content.html: Just checking: If I understand correctly, when the topic doesn't exist, we create an entry in the map for it. However, if the type doesn't exist, we return. Is there any reason for not creating the type and continue advertising the topic?
